Activate Yeast – Warm Water Preparation

Locate the sterilized 1000ml beaker. Ensure the beaker is clean and dry. Visually inspect the beaker's interior for any remaining residue. If residue is present, carefully wipe the interior surface with a lint-free cloth dampened with 70% isopropyl alcohol, rotating the beaker 360 degrees, for a duration of 5 seconds.

Measure 800ml of distilled water into the sterilized 1000ml beaker. Using a calibrated measuring cylinder, precisely pour the water from a height of 30cm, aiming for the center of the beaker. Allow the water to settle for exactly 15 seconds to ensure complete pooling.

Using a thermometer with a resolution of 0.1°C, place the thermometer stem into the distilled water. Ensure the bulb of the thermometer is submerged at least 2cm below the water surface. Maintain a stable position for 30 seconds to allow for temperature stabilization.

Record the initial water temperature reading from the thermometer. Note the reading precisely to the nearest tenth of a degree Celsius. Using a permanent marker, record the temperature on a dedicated log sheet. Verify the reading against a secondary thermometer if available.

Activate the heating element. Set the heating plate to a temperature of 38°C. Monitor the temperature reading on the heating plate to ensure it stabilizes within 2 minutes. Adjust the heating plate power to maintain the 38°C target temperature within +/- 0.5°C.

Maintain the water temperature at 38°C. Observe the water temperature continuously using the thermometer. Adjust the heating plate power in 1-degree Celsius increments every 60 seconds until the temperature is consistently 38.0°C +/- 0.1°C. Note each power adjustment on the log sheet.

Once the water temperature is stable at 38.0°C +/- 0.1°C, prepare the temperature probe. Attach the temperature probe to the side of the beaker, ensuring the probe is submerged approximately 2cm below the water surface. Verify probe connection.

Prepare the digital temperature display. Turn on the digital temperature display. Ensure it is calibrated according to the manufacturer's instructions. Verify the display is reading 38.0°C +/- 0.1°C within 30 seconds.

Begin continuous temperature monitoring.  Use the digital temperature display to monitor the water temperature every 5 seconds for the next 10 minutes. Record each temperature reading, along with the time, on the log sheet.
Measure Water Temperature – Target Yeast Activation Temperature

Retrieve Thermometer: Locate the digital thermometer (resolution 0.1°C) and ensure it is in its default, resting position on a stable, level surface. The surface should be free of direct sunlight or other heat sources. Verify the battery level is above 75%.

Prepare the Water Source: Fill a clean, sanitized 250ml beaker with distilled water. Ensure the beaker is completely full, with no air bubbles trapped at the surface. Observe the water level visually; it should reach exactly 249.9ml, measured using a calibrated measuring cylinder. Record this precise volume in a notebook.

Initial Water Temperature Measurement: Place the thermometer's sensing bulb precisely in the center of the water, ensuring the bulb is fully submerged and motionless. Wait for 10 seconds for the reading to stabilize to within 0.05°C. Note the initial water temperature reading (T1) on the thermometer display. Record T1 precisely, including the decimal place.

Controlled Heating (Stage 1): Using a hotplate with a precise temperature control (resolution 0.1°C), set the temperature to 28.0°C. Monitor the water temperature every 30 seconds for the next 3 minutes. Record each temperature reading as it appears on the hotplate's display, noting the exact time of each measurement (e.g., 3:00:00, 3:03:00, etc.).

Yeast Activation Observation: Simultaneously, prepare a small test tube containing 10ml of yeast suspension (manufacturer's recommended concentration) within a clean, sanitized environment.  Observe the yeast suspension for 60 seconds, noting any visible changes (e.g., bubbling, foam formation, color change). Record the time and detailed observation of these changes in your notebook.

Temperature Adjustment (Stage 2): Increase the hotplate temperature by 0.5°C every 2 minutes, maintaining a total increase over 10 minutes. Monitor the water temperature every minute. Record the water temperature and the exact time of each measurement.

Yeast Activity Assessment: Continue monitoring the yeast suspension in the test tube, observing for signs of activity (bubbling, foam, color change) every 30 seconds. Record the time and detailed observation of activity in your notebook.  Document any changes, noting the level of intensity (e.g., slight bubbling, moderate bubbling, vigorous bubbling).

Target Temperature Identification: Continue heating the water until the water temperature reaches 28.8°C.  Record the exact water temperature reading when it stabilizes.  Note the time of measurement precisely.

Yeast Activation Confirmation: Observe the yeast suspension again for an additional 60 seconds, meticulously documenting any changes in activity level (bubbling, foam, color change, etc.) and recording the time. Note the exact time of the final observation.

Final Data Recording: Record the final water temperature (T2) on the thermometer display, along with the time of measurement. Also, record the final observation of the yeast suspension activity level and the time of observation. Clearly state your findings as the yeast activation temperature.
Add Sugar to Water – Yeast Food

Locate a clean, dry measuring cup. Ensure the cup is free of any debris or residue. Visually inspect the interior surface for cleanliness. If any residue is present, wipe the cup with a lint-free cloth dampened with distilled water, drying thoroughly afterwards.

Retrieve a digital scale capable of measuring in grams. Ensure the scale is placed on a stable, level surface. Calibrate the scale according to the manufacturer's instructions. Verify accuracy by placing a known weight (e.g., a standard 100g weight) on the scale and confirming the reading is within 0.1g of the expected value.

Carefully pour exactly 20.0 grams of granulated white sugar into the center of the calibrated digital scale. Maintain a steady, consistent pouring motion. Observe the scale display, noting the exact weight reading as the sugar is added. Stop pouring precisely when the display reads 20.0 grams. Record the exact time of the measurement (e.g., 14:32:15).

Using a clean, dry spoon, scoop precisely 20.0 grams of the granulated sugar from the scale platform. Gently lift the spoon straight up, maintaining a consistent height of 3.0 centimeters above the scale platform. Avoid any tilting or dragging of the spoon across the scale surface.

Carefully transfer the 20.0 grams of sugar from the spoon into a clean, dry 1-liter container of lukewarm water. The water temperature should be between 30°C and 35°C. Slowly lower the spoon into the water, ensuring the entire scoop of sugar is submerged immediately. Hold the spoon vertically for precisely 3 seconds before gently lifting it straight up.

Visually confirm that all of the sugar has completely dissolved into the water. Observe the water’s surface for 10 seconds. If any undissolved sugar remains, gently stir the mixture with a clean, dry spoon for exactly 5 seconds, using a circular motion, starting from the center of the container and moving outwards.

Using a clean, dry measuring cup, measure out 100 milliliters (100 ml) of the sugar water mixture. Carefully pour the water from the 1-liter container into the 100ml measuring cup. Ensure the water level reaches exactly the 100ml mark on the measuring cup. Verify the level visually, confirming it is level with the indicated mark. Record the time (e.g., 14:33:02).

Discard the remaining sugar water mixture in the 1-liter container into a designated waste disposal area, ensuring no splashing occurs. Wipe down the interior of the 1-liter container with a clean, damp cloth, followed by a dry cloth to remove any residual moisture.
Sprinkle Yeast into Water – Initiate Blooming
Locate a 1-cup (237 ml) measuring cup and a small whisk. Ensure both are clean and dry.

Pour 1 cup (237 ml) of lukewarm water (between 98°F and 105°F or 37°C and 40.6°C) into a medium-sized ceramic or glass bowl. Use a thermometer to confirm the water temperature falls within the specified range. Allow the water to sit for 30 seconds to stabilize.
Using a clean, dry fingertip, gently stir the water in a clockwise direction for 5 seconds. This ensures consistent temperature distribution and removes any potential surface moisture.
Retrieve a packet of active dry yeast (typically 7g). Carefully open the packet using a clean, dry knife. Maintain a 10-degree angle to prevent spillage.
Using a small spoon, measure precisely 7 grams of active dry yeast from the packet. Ensure the entire weight is transferred to a separate small, clean bowl. Do not pour directly into the water.

Holding the small spoon vertically, slowly and steadily pour the measured yeast into the bowl containing the lukewarm water. Aim for the exact center of the water surface. The pour should take no longer than 2 seconds.

Immediately using the small whisk, gently whisk the mixture in a circular motion for 10 seconds. Maintain a consistent speed of 30-40 rotations per minute. Observe the mixture for 3 seconds to ensure the yeast is fully incorporated.
Observe the mixture for 60 seconds. Look for signs of blooming, such as the formation of small bubbles rising to the surface. A full bloom indicates successful activation.
If no signs of blooming are observed after 60 seconds, gently stir the mixture again with the whisk for 5 more seconds. Monitor for another 30 seconds before proceeding with the next step.
Observe Yeast Bloom – Verify Activity

1. Prepare the Workspace: Clear a 10cm x 10cm area on a clean, non-porous surface (e.g., stainless steel or glass). Ensure the surface is completely dry. Place a sterile, disposable wipe (7cm x 7cm) on the work area. Wipe the surface with 70% isopropyl alcohol, allowing it to air dry for precisely 60 seconds. Dispose of the used wipe immediately.

2. Prepare the Yeast Culture: Using sterile tweezers, carefully remove one (1) 5mm diameter agar plate containing *Saccharomyces cerevisiae* yeast from its storage container. Position the plate so the agar surface is facing upwards. Ensure the plate remains stationary.

3. Positioning the Plate: Using the sterile tweezers, gently lift the plate and position it precisely 25cm directly in front of the observer’s eye line. Maintain a vertical orientation, ensuring the agar surface is parallel to the floor. Confirm the plate's position by measuring the distance from the observer’s eye to the center of the agar surface using a standard ruler (resolution: 1mm). Record this distance as the ‘Initial Observation Distance’.

4. Illumination Setup: Position a small, focused LED light source (wavelength: 580-620nm, intensity: 500 lux) 15cm to the right of the plate. The light should be directed at a 20-degree angle relative to the plate's surface. Adjust the light's angle until the agar surface is evenly illuminated without creating excessive glare. Use a lux meter to confirm the light intensity is within the specified range.

5. Observation Start: Begin timing with a digital stopwatch (resolution: 0.1 seconds). Observe the agar surface continuously for exactly 60 seconds. Maintain a stationary gaze, focusing on the center of the agar surface. Note any visual changes, such as the formation of yeast colonies, color changes (e.g., from transparent to opaque), or movement of yeast cells.

6. Colony Identification (if present): If visible colonies form, record their diameter using a calibrated digital caliper (resolution: 0.1mm) at the smallest diameter point of the colony. Measure three (3) distinct colonies and record their diameters. Note the colony's color and texture (e.g., smooth, granular).

7. Movement Observation (if present): During the 60-second observation period, note any movement of yeast cells within the colony or adjacent to the colony. Record the direction and speed of movement (e.g., ‘Slow, circular motion’ or ‘Rapid, random movement’). Observe for at least 10 seconds between measurements if movement is present to minimize observer bias.

8. Final Observation Recording: At the 60-second mark, stop the stopwatch. Record the elapsed time (in seconds). Note any final observations regarding yeast activity, including the total number of visible colonies, the largest colony diameter, and any ongoing movement.
9. Environmental Monitoring: Record the ambient temperature (resolution: 0.1°C) and relative humidity (resolution: 1%) of the observation environment. These parameters may influence yeast activity.
10. Plate Disposal: Carefully dispose of the agar plate in a designated biohazard container according to laboratory protocols. Do not touch the agar surface with bare hands.
Cover Dough – Create Rising Environment

Prepare Workspace: Clear a 24-inch diameter circular area on a clean, stainless steel countertop. Ensure the surface is completely dry and free of any debris. Place a silicone mat, 12 inches in diameter, precisely centered within the cleared area. The silicone mat’s surface should be taut and wrinkle-free.

Dough Retrieval: Using a heat-resistant silicone spatula, carefully lift the dough from its proofing container. Maintain a consistent upward motion, no more than 5 centimeters in height, to avoid excessive degassing. Hold the spatula approximately 15 centimeters above the silicone mat. Maintain a constant, gentle pressure to minimize disturbance to the dough's structure.

Dough Placement: Slowly lower the spatula with the dough onto the center of the silicone mat. Control the descent speed to ensure the dough lands gently, with an initial drop height of no more than 3 centimeters. Monitor the dough’s initial contact with the mat; aim for a uniform spread across the 12-inch diameter.

Initial Shaping (Phase 1): Using the flat edge of the silicone spatula, begin a slow, 6-inch diameter circular motion, maintaining a consistent speed of 2 revolutions per second. This motion should be applied for exactly 30 seconds. Observe the dough’s surface and ensure it maintains a uniform thickness of approximately 2 millimeters.

Initial Shaping (Phase 2): Rotate the silicone mat 90 degrees clockwise. Repeat the same 6-inch diameter circular motion, with the same speed of 2 revolutions per second, for exactly 30 seconds. Monitor dough spread and adjust gently if necessary.

Repeat Rotation & Shaping: Rotate the silicone mat another 90 degrees clockwise. Repeat the 6-inch diameter circular shaping motion for 30 seconds. Confirm consistent diameter and even dough distribution.

Final Dough Assessment: Using the silicone spatula, gently lift a 5-centimeter section of the dough from the center of the mat. Examine the dough's surface. The surface should exhibit a smooth, uniform texture with minimal deflation. Adjust shaping if significant deflation or unevenness is observed.

Covering: Immediately place a 20-centimeter diameter, 3-millimeter thick, parchment paper circle over the shaped dough. Ensure the circle’s edge extends 2 centimeters beyond the dough's perimeter. Center the parchment paper precisely over the dough.
Securing Cover: Gently press down on the parchment paper with the silicone spatula, applying even pressure for 2 seconds. This ensures complete contact between the parchment and the dough surface.

Environment Shielding: Immediately place a 30-centimeter diameter, 5-millimeter thick, clear acrylic dome over the parchment paper and dough. Center the dome precisely over the dough. Secure the dome with a 5-centimeter diameter rubber band, applying gentle, even pressure around the dome's perimeter.
Monitor Dough Rise – Check for Expansion
Locate the Dough Ball: Identify the primary dough ball on the baking sheet. Ensure the sheet is resting on a stable, level surface. Verify the surface is clean and free of debris.

Establish Baseline Height: Using a ruler with millimeter precision, measure the vertical distance from the top surface of the dough to the highest point of the dough. Record this measurement in millimeters. Maintain this ruler in a fixed position directly above the center of the dough ball.
Initiate Timer: Activate a digital timer set to 60 seconds. Ensure the timer displays clearly and audibly, with a distinct beep at the 60-second mark.

Observe Dough Expansion - 15 Seconds: For the first 15 seconds of the timer, visually monitor the dough. Specifically, note any change in the height of the tallest point of the dough. Record the height in millimeters at 10-second intervals (10mm, 20mm, 30mm). Document your observations in a notebook with a timestamp.

Observe Dough Expansion - 30 Seconds: For the next 30 seconds of the timer, continue to visually monitor the dough. Record the height of the tallest point of the dough every 5 seconds (5mm, 10mm, 15mm, 20mm, 25mm, 30mm). Document your observations in a notebook with a timestamp.

Observe Dough Expansion - 45 Seconds: For the next 15 seconds of the timer, continue to visually monitor the dough. Record the height of the tallest point of the dough every 5 seconds (5mm, 10mm, 15mm, 20mm, 25mm, 30mm). Document your observations in a notebook with a timestamp.

Observe Dough Expansion - 60 Seconds: At the 60-second mark of the timer, immediately record the height of the tallest point of the dough using the ruler. This constitutes the final measurement. Note the exact reading in millimeters.
Analyze Expansion Rate: Calculate the total height increase from the initial baseline measurement to the final measurement. Express this difference in millimeters. Record this value.

Record Observations: In your notebook, summarize all measurements taken at each interval (10s, 5s, and final), along with the calculated total height increase. Include a brief qualitative description of the dough’s texture and appearance (e.g., ‘rising rapidly,’ ‘rising slowly,’ ‘sticky,’ ‘smooth’).
Document Environmental Factors: Note any relevant environmental factors that may have influenced the dough's rise (e.g., room temperature, humidity, presence of drafts).
Shape Dough
Prepare Water for Yeast Activation

Locate a clean, food-grade plastic pitcher. Ensure the pitcher is free of any debris or residue. Visually inspect the interior surface for imperfections and wipe with a damp, lint-free cloth. Dry thoroughly with a clean, dry microfiber towel. Confirm dryness by gently tapping the pitcher - it should produce a clear, resonant sound.

Measure 300 milliliters of lukewarm water (between 32°C and 38°C) using a calibrated measuring cup. Pour the water directly into the clean pitcher, ensuring no water spills onto the counter surface. Verify the volume visually, aligning the cup’s markings with your eye, focusing on the meniscus.

Place the pitcher on a stable, level surface. Position the surface at least 60 centimeters above the floor to minimize vibration transfer. Observe the water for 5 seconds, confirming it remains undisturbed.

Retrieve a packet of active dry yeast (approximately 7 grams). Using a clean, dry spoon, gently break the yeast packet open, separating the contents. Avoid pouring any granules directly into the water.

Slowly sprinkle the entire contents of the yeast packet onto the surface of the water. Distribute the yeast evenly across the water’s surface using a gentle, circular motion with the spoon. Maintain a consistent speed of approximately 2 rotations per second.

Using a clean, sanitized stirring utensil (plastic or silicone), gently stir the water and yeast in a clockwise direction for exactly 15 seconds. Maintain a consistent stirring speed – approximately 10 rotations per second. Avoid vigorous stirring to prevent damaging the yeast cells.

Observe the water for 30 seconds. Note any visible signs of foaming or bubbling. A small amount of foam is normal, but excessive bubbling indicates potential issues with the yeast or water temperature.

If minimal foam persists after 30 seconds, cover the pitcher with a clean, tightly fitting lid. This will help retain warmth and encourage yeast activation. Ensure the lid is properly seated to prevent heat loss.
Maintain the covered pitcher at room temperature (approximately 20°C - 25°C) for a minimum of 15 minutes to allow the yeast to fully activate and begin consuming the sugar.
Measure Water Volume Accurately

1. Retrieve Measuring Vessel: Locate a graduated cylinder with clearly marked volume measurements in milliliters (mL) ranging from 0 to 100 mL. Verify the scale is consistently aligned and free from significant scratches or distortions that might impede accurate reading. The cylinder should be positioned on a stable, level surface.

2. Position Cylinder Level: Gently place the graduated cylinder on a flat, horizontal surface. Using a straight edge (a ruler or similar) ensure the cylinder's base is perfectly level. Adjust the cylinder's position by subtly shifting it until the bottom surface is parallel to the surface.

3. Add Initial Water: Using a clean, disposable measuring cup (with 10mL or 50mL markings for convenient addition), measure 20 mL of distilled water. Pour this water slowly and steadily into the graduated cylinder, maintaining a consistent flow rate. Observe the water level rise, noting the exact point where the meniscus begins to curve.

4. Stabilize Water Level: Once the water has entered the cylinder, allow the water level to stabilize for precisely 5 seconds. During this time, do not disturb the cylinder. Observe the water level intently, noting the position of the meniscus – this is crucial for accurate measurement.

5. Read Meniscus Position: With the water level fully stabilized, visually align your eye with the lowest point of the meniscus. Ensure your eye is at the same horizontal level as the bottom of the meniscus. Record the volume reading from the graduated cylinder. Record this reading as ‘23.5 mL’ (using a specific, identified example).
6. Repeat Addition (if needed): If a greater volume is required

7. Final Stabilization: After adding the additional water, allow the water level to stabilize for another 5 seconds. Ensure the meniscus is no longer moving before taking the final reading. Confirm the reading is recorded as ‘28.5 mL’.
8. Clean Up: Carefully dispose of the measured water. Thoroughly rinse the graduated cylinder with distilled water and dry it with a lint-free cloth. Store the cylinder in a clean, dry location.
Warm Water to Yeast Activation Temperature
Locate the mixing bowl. Ensure the bowl is clean and dry. Verify the bowl's interior diameter measures precisely 23 centimeters (9.06 inches). Record this measurement in a digital notepad.
Retrieve the thermometer. Confirm the thermometer's digital display is functioning correctly and is calibrated to Fahrenheit. Set the thermometer to a continuous temperature reading mode.
Measure 300 milliliters (10.5 fluid ounces) of filtered water and pour it into the mixing bowl. Use a measuring jug with a graduated volume marking that is accurate to ±1 milliliter.

Place the thermometer into the water within the mixing bowl. Ensure the thermometer's sensing tip is fully submerged, approximately 3 centimeters (1.18 inches) below the water surface. Maintain this position throughout the activation process.

Activate the tap providing the filtered water. Adjust the water flow to a steady, gentle stream – approximately 5 milliliters per second. Maintain this flow rate consistently throughout the activation stage.

Using a clean, dry thermometer probe, slowly introduce 10 grams (0.35 ounces) of active dry yeast into the water. Time the introduction from the moment the yeast makes contact with the water. The introduction should take precisely 3 seconds.

Immediately after yeast introduction, begin gently stirring the water with a clean, sanitized rubber spatula. Stir in a clockwise motion for 15 seconds. Maintain a constant stirring speed – avoid rushing or pausing.

Monitor the water temperature on the thermometer. Record the initial temperature reading as 'Initial Temperature'. Wait for the water temperature to stabilize and reach 98.9 degrees Fahrenheit (37 degrees Celsius) within a 60-second window. Indicate this stabilization by recording the final temperature as 'Activated Temperature'.

After confirming the 'Activated Temperature' of 98.9°F (37°C), cease stirring. Remove the thermometer from the water. Observe the water for 10 seconds, noting any visual changes, such as the formation of bubbles or foam. Document any observations in the digital notepad.
Dispose of the water and yeast mixture according to local sanitation guidelines. Sanitize the mixing bowl and spatula using a food-safe disinfectant solution. Rinse thoroughly with potable water.
Add Sugar to Water – Yeast Food
Locate a measuring cup with clearly marked volume increments (milliliters). Ensure the cup is clean and dry. Verify the markings are readable without distortion.

Using a clean, dry teaspoon, carefully scoop 10 milliliters of granulated sugar from the sugar container. Maintain a consistent scoop height of approximately 1 centimeter above the sugar surface. Avoid creating a sugar dust cloud.
Precisely pour the 10 milliliters of granulated sugar into the center of the measuring cup. Observe the sugar settling within the cup, ensuring there are no sugar clumps forming against the sides.

Using a clean, dry measuring cup with clearly marked volume increments (milliliters), fill the cup completely with distilled water. Ensure the water level reaches the maximum mark on the cup, without overflowing.

Carefully pour the distilled water from the measuring cup into a small, clean mixing bowl. Maintain a pouring angle of approximately 30 degrees relative to the bowl's rim. Pour for a duration of 2.5 seconds, measuring this time with a stopwatch if necessary.

Using a clean, dry teaspoon, scoop 5 milliliters of granulated sugar. Ensure the scoop height is consistent with previous measurements (approximately 1 centimeter). Gently tap the measuring cup on a flat surface three times to dislodge any remaining sugar granules.

Carefully pour the 5 milliliters of granulated sugar into the bowl containing the distilled water. Observe the sugar dissolving process, noting the time it takes for complete dissolution (approximately 15-30 seconds).
Using a clean, dry teaspoon, scoop an additional 2.5 milliliters of granulated sugar. Perform the same consistent scoop height technique (approximately 1 centimeter). Add this sugar to the bowl.

Thoroughly mix the mixture in the bowl using a clean, dry spoon. Stir in a circular motion, beginning from the center of the bowl and moving outwards for a total duration of 5 seconds. Ensure all sugar granules are completely dissolved.

Visually inspect the mixture. The solution should be completely clear with no visible sugar particles remaining. If sugar crystals are still visible, repeat step 10, stirring for an additional 5 seconds.
Sprinkle Yeast into Water – Initiate Blooming
Locate a clean, dry measuring cup with a volume of 1/4 cup (approximately 60 milliliters). Ensure the cup is free of any residue or contamination. Place the measuring cup on a stable, level surface.

Retrieve a packet of active dry yeast – a standard 7-gram packet. Carefully open the packet, taking care not to spill any of the yeast granules. Use a flat, clean surface (e.g., a cutting board) to open the packet to minimize dust creation.

Using a clean, dry teaspoon, gently scoop approximately 7 grams of active dry yeast from the packet. Do not compact the yeast; allow the granules to remain loose. Visually confirm that you have collected approximately 7 grams – this will be a visual estimate; aim for a volume roughly equivalent to a small, rounded scoop.
Pour the measured yeast granules into a 10-ounce (284 ml) glass measuring cup. Ensure the yeast is evenly distributed across the bottom of the cup.

Add 1 cup (237 ml) of lukewarm water to the measuring cup with the yeast. The water temperature should be between 95°F and 105°F (35°C and 40°C). Use a thermometer to verify the water temperature. If the water is too cold, add 1/2 teaspoon of sugar to warm it slightly. If it's too hot, allow it to cool for 5 minutes.

Using a clean, dry stirring utensil (e.g., a small silicone spatula or spoon), gently stir the yeast and water mixture for exactly 30 seconds. Stir in a circular motion, ensuring that all yeast granules are submerged in the water. Maintain a consistent stirring speed – approximately 20-30 rotations per second.

Allow the yeast mixture to sit undisturbed for 5-10 minutes. Observe the mixture for signs of activity, such as the formation of a foamy layer on the surface. The foamy layer indicates that the yeast is becoming active.

After 5-10 minutes, visually assess the mixture. If a significant, stable foamy layer has formed (approximately 1/2 inch or 12 mm thick), the yeast is considered activated and ready for use. If no significant foam is present after 10 minutes, the yeast may be inactive and should be discarded and replaced.
Carefully note the time elapsed since the beginning of the activation process. This information will be useful for recipe timing.
Clean and dry the measuring cup and stirring utensil thoroughly before discarding or storing them.
Observe Yeast Bloom – Verify Activity

Locate the Yeast Culture: Using a calibrated ruler, measure the distance from the floor to the center of the yeast culture container. Record this measurement in millimeters (mm). Note the precise location of the container within the room, specifying the nearest wall and its distance from the container’s edge (also in mm).

Prepare the Magnifying Glass: Ensure the magnifying glass is clean. Using a lint-free microfiber cloth, gently wipe the lens surface in a circular motion, starting from the center and working outwards. Verify the lens is free of smudges and scratches by observing a distant, brightly lit object through the lens; the image should be sharp and undistorted for at least 3 seconds. Adjust the focus knob until the image is perfectly clear.

Establish the Observation Point: Position yourself 30 centimeters (300mm) directly to the right of the yeast culture container, maintaining a perpendicular angle to the container’s surface. Use the calibrated ruler to measure the distance from your eye to the center of the container, recording this distance in millimeters. Note your exact posture: head level, shoulders relaxed, arms at your sides. Maintain this position.

Initial Observation - 60 Second Scan: Begin observing the yeast culture. Using the magnifying glass, systematically scan the entire surface of the culture, starting at the top-left corner and moving horizontally across the surface in a consistent, linear motion. Cover the entire surface area of the culture (approximately 10cm x 10cm) with a single, continuous scan. Record the duration of this initial scan to the nearest second.

Identify Bloom Indicators: Within the scanned area, carefully observe for the presence of yeast ‘bloom’ – defined as the formation of visible, expanding colonies of yeast cells. Identify at least three distinct areas exhibiting bloom formation, each at least 1mm in diameter. Precisely measure the diameter of each bloom using the magnifying glass and a calibrated ruler (recorded in millimeters).

Documentation - Bloom 1: Take a photograph of the first identified bloom using a digital camera. Adjust the camera settings to a fixed ISO of 100 and a fixed aperture of f/8. Ensure the image is well-lit and the focus is sharp. Record the camera’s GPS coordinates and the exact time of the photograph. Note the color of the bloom in the photograph (e.g., pale yellow, creamy white).
Repeat Documentation (Blooms 2 & 3): Following the same procedure as for Bloom 1, document Blooms 2 and 3 with photographs and recorded metadata (GPS coordinates, time, color).

Post-Observation Check: After completing all documentation, visually inspect the yeast culture again, focusing on the areas where bloom was initially observed. Note any changes in the bloom's size, shape, or color. Record any observations regarding the surrounding environment – temperature, humidity, lighting – and note these in a separate log.
Mix Dough

Locate and retrieve a mixing bowl, approximately 2.5 liters in volume, from its storage location. Ensure the bowl is clean and dry, with no visible residue or moisture. Position the bowl on a stable, level countertop surface, approximately 60 centimeters from the floor.

Using a digital kitchen scale, accurately measure 500 grams of all-purpose flour (specifically, unbleached, medium-protein flour) into the center of the mixing bowl. Ensure the scale is calibrated and displaying '0.00g' before initiating the measurement. Verify the flour is evenly distributed across the bottom of the bowl.

Measure 350 milliliters of lukewarm water (temperature between 37-40 degrees Celsius) into a separate measuring cup. Use a thermometer to confirm the water's temperature falls within the specified range. Slowly pour the water into the mixing bowl, starting from the opposite side of the bowl from where the flour was placed. Distribute the water evenly across the flour.

Add 10 milliliters of olive oil (extra virgin, approximately 0.5% acidity) to the mixing bowl. Using a measuring spoon, precisely measure the olive oil and add it to the center of the bowl. Rotate the bowl one quarter turn clockwise to incorporate the oil into the water and flour mixture.

Add 7 grams of fine sea salt (sodium chloride, particle size <0.5mm) to the mixing bowl. Using a dedicated measuring spoon, accurately measure the salt and add it to the center of the bowl. Gently break up any clumps of salt with a spatula before adding it to the mixture.

Initiate mixing using a stand mixer with a dough hook attachment. Set the mixer speed to level 2 (approximately 60 RPM). Begin mixing for 80 seconds. Observe the dough consistency, noting its initial stickiness.

After 80 seconds, reduce the mixer speed to level 3 (approximately 80 RPM). Continue mixing for an additional 60 seconds. Monitor the dough's development, looking for signs of gluten formation – a smoother, more elastic texture.

With the mixer still running at level 3, add 1 teaspoon (5 milliliters) of instant dry yeast to the dough. Immediately increase the mixer speed to level 4 (approximately 100 RPM) for 30 seconds to fully incorporate the yeast. Reduce speed back to level 3 for a further 30 seconds.

Turn off the mixer. Using a spatula, gently scrape down the sides and bottom of the mixing bowl to ensure all the dough is fully incorporated. Fold the dough over itself three times, rotating the bowl 90 degrees after each fold. This should take approximately 15 seconds.

Cover the mixing bowl tightly with a damp, clean kitchen towel. Place the bowl in a warm location (approximately 27-32 degrees Celsius) for a rising time of 60-90 minutes, or until the dough has doubled in size.
